0.user_question: Chase and Rider can ride their bikes thrice a day for 5 days; but on two other days, they ride twice the times they do on usual days. How many times do they ride their bikes a week?

subanswer.text: Without any extra considerations, both individuals typically ride once every day across five typical days (since one cycle per day constitutes an individual session). Hence, over those initial five days without modifications or additions from special instances, they will together cover ten sessions since each person covers one single round trip daily [(Chase+Rider) x NumberOfTypicalDays]. The answer is Ten.

0.user_question: Chase and Rider can ride their bikes thrice a day for 5 days; but on two other days, they ride twice the times they do on usual days. How many times do they ride their bikes a week?

direct_answer.text: First let’s determine Chase and Riders regular bike riding schedule per week without additional activities. They usually ride three (3) times every day which amounts to `3*x`=15 rides during normalcy (`x` being any arbitrary unit). However it was mentioned that aside this routine, these kids also took part in extra fun cycling sessions amounting to `(double quantity)*(extra activity)` or equivalently `[3*(2)]*`[2]=12 additional cycles within said period. By simple arithmetic computation we get Total Cycle Count Per Week as Summation Of Normal Routine And Extra Activity That Is [Total Regular Biking Time]+[(Extra Fun Times)*NumberOfSpecialDays] Hence ,we simply add up our numbers i.e., `RegularBikeRidesPerWeek+AdditionalFunCycles`. This translates mathematically into : `Sum([Normal Bike Roundups]* NumberofStandard Days)+Sum([Double Quantity](ExtraActivity))`, Substituting numerical values yields us ;

0.user_question: Chase and Rider can ride their bikes thrice a day for 5 days; but on two other days, they ride twice the times they do on usual days. How many times do they ride their bikes a week?

1.subquestion: How many bike rides occur during regular days (non-extra) per person?

subanswer.text: Regularly, both Chase and Rider can ride their bikes thrice a day over five non-extra days, meaning each will make 3 x 5 = 15 trips individually from these standard days. The answer is 15.

2.subquestion: How many additional trips take place due to extra riding sessions?

subanswer.text: As stated, Chase and Rider choose an alternative schedule whereby they go cycling double the number of times compared to those normal days on one particular occasion within the span of seven days. Consequently, doubling up would result in another set of daily ridings equaling twice what normally occurs. Specifically speaking about our single instance here, such instances account for 3 cycles taken again plus another triple cycle – yielding altogether 6+3=9 added individual journeys throughout said period. Thus nine unique events fall under 'additional'. 0.user_question: Chase and Rider can ride their bikes thrice a day for 5 days; but on two other days, they ride twice the times they do on usual days. How many times do they ride their bikes a week?

direct_answer.text: First let’s determine Chase and Riders regular bike riding schedule per week without additional activities. They usually ride three (3) times every day which amounts to `3*x`=15 rides during normalcy (`x` being any arbitrary unit). However it was mentioned that aside this routine, these kids also took part in extra fun cycling sessions amounting to `(double quantity)*(extra activity)` or equivalently `[3*(2)]*`[2]=12 additional cycles within said period. By simple arithmetic computation we get Total Cycle Count Per Week as Summation Of Normal Routine And Extra Activity That Is [Total Regular Biking Time]+[(Extra Fun Times)*NumberOfSpecialDays] Hence ,we simply add up our numbers i.e., `RegularBikeRidesPerWeek+AdditionalFunCycles`. This translates mathematically into : `Sum([Normal Bike Roundups]* NumberofStandard Days)+Sum([Double Quantity](ExtraActivity))`, Substituting numerical values yields us ;
